page.title: 01 THE PARISH OF BEGUILDY
page.content: The area which we are studying is in the parish of Beguildy and comprises the villages of Beguildy and Felindre. The river runs along the eastern edge of the parish and forms part of the border between England and Wales. The valley has steep sides, rising to a height of over five hundred metres. It is a rural area with numerous small farms specialising in rearing sheep and store cattle. The river meanders considerably on its route through the valley and causes problems of erosion in several areas. During this survey the highways department are busily changing the course of the river at a point between Beguildy and Felindre because of damage to the road. Lower down the valley a scheme is in operation to move the roadway away from the river.
